comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: 292 King Street, Newtown, NSW 2042 Opened by Governor Duff on Monday 14/08/1893. See wonderful full description in SMH 15/08/1893 p.5 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13934247 . The locals were whingeing about the lack of a clock (as in this photo) - they always seem to have been installed much later - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13915498 . Clock started in April 1900 - SMH 07/04/1900 p.5 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14304379 . So this photo is between 1893-1900 . From the vignetting, I would say closer to 1893. Google Street View is good - not much has changed in 120 years, except the street windows - g.co/maps/53y3g And a 'now' view from Newtown Wikipedia entry -

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Don't forget the street numbering on King Street changed during this period. In 1893 the new Post Office was at 202 King Street (first post and telegraph master was Joseph E. Lees Lee). Thomas Harrison, ironmonger, was trading next door at 204 (see Sands 1894). By late 1895 the numbering had changed to 292 and 294 respectively (see Sands 1896). C. G. Hatte, draper and clothier, had expanded to include Harrison's former premises at 294 by late 1899 (see Sands 1900) - which narrows our date range a further year ...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet]Ha,  I never knew that!  I cannot see any numbers to tell whether this is pre or post 1895.

There might be a tramway expert who knows when this line was electrified. 

I wonder if Joseph Edwin Lees was one of the folk outside?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I remembered the renumbering issue from this one - www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5763368192/ I think the postmaster's name was actually Lee, not Lees. Sands has Lees for the first few years but thereafter has Lee. And your newspaper article about the opening has Lee.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Quite right - my error! Sorry, Mr Lee. The description of the new Post Office and the staff from the opening newspaper article is worth reproducing -
" The new structure, which stands at the corner of King-street and the Erskineville-road, cost the Department about £4700. It is of imposing appearance, built in red brick, with stone dressings, in the style known as a free rendering of the Dutch Renaissance. The interior is apportioned as follows - Public lobby, 36ft. x 13ft telegraph operating-room, 12 x10 general office, 27 x 30 , sorting-room, 32 x 21 and private office, 14 x 12. There is also a residence for the postmaster, consisting of drawing-room, dining-room, kitchen, bathroom and offices, and four bedrooms. Mr. J. Edwin Lee is tho post and telegraph master in charge. He has under him three assistants, two operators and a probationer, five telegraph messengers, three receiver-clearers, and about 20 postmen. ... "

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
... and our old friend Walter Liberty Vernon, architect.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet/6986165490/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/people/state-records-nsw/] There is another contemporary photo of this fine building in your catalogue which has the wrong title "Rozelle" - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... Found via "HARRISON IRONMONGER" sign on both photos (see [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet]'s note)
